Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Sahara Dust Layers on Convective Cloud Development and Precipitation over the Tropical Eastern Atlantic Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The indirect effect currently produces the greatest uncertainty in climate predictions among all known climate forcing mechanisms. Although tropical deep-convective cloud systems have great impacts on large-scale atmospheric circulation, few studies investigate the aerosol impacts on deep convective cloud systems. To improve our understanding of the aerosol indirect effect, and to better quantify their role in regional and global climate changes requires innovative approaches.

Intellectual Merit
The overarching goal of this research is to utilize comprehensive observation analysis and cloud resolving simulations using Weather Research and Forecast (WRF) model coupled with a spectral bin microphysics (SBM) scheme to assess how mineral dust affects the development of tropical deep-convective cloud systems, and to understand mechanisms responsible for the observed changes of dust indirect effect. The combination of our integrated satellite and in-situ data from multiple instruments/platforms and our innovative analysis techniques will greatly benefit research community to address key questions of aerosol-cloud interaction and to develop and validate the realistic representation of aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions in advanced models on regional and global climate model-grid scales. Two outcomes are expected from this research effort, i.e., (1) the mechanisms responsible for the observed changes in convective core, stratiform/anvil, and precipitation from the dust-free sector to the dust sector, and (2) an estimation of the changes in cloud properties and precipitation imposed by dusts on the deep convective clouds.

Broader Impact
As one of the major sources of aerosols, Saharan dust can be transported across the tropical North Atlantic and into the Caribbean region as well as into Europe. Dust affects cloud properties by the semi-direct effect through changing the radiative heating, and by the indirect effect through acting as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) and ice nuclei (IN). The heterogeneous nucleation imposed by dust occurs at warmer temperature in a deep convective cloud could potentially change the vertical profile of latent heat and the vertical distribution of supercooled water. These changes in the tropical deep convective systems will have substantial impacts on large scale circulation as well. Nevertheless, the aerosol-cloud interaction is the least understood aspect in the climate system, of which our understanding of the impact of aerosols on mixed-phase and ice clouds by acting as ice nuclei (IN) is the poorest. It is vital to have comprehensive observations and model simulation to assess and understand the physical processes of the indirect and semi-direct effects of dust aerosols on clouds. The outcomes of this work will complement our understanding of aerosol-cloud-climate interactions and benefit the climate community to estimate of the contribution of dust to climate change. Through student training and education outreach, students from various levels will gain some understanding on current climate issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has sought to improve the understanding of the effects of dust on ice formation processes and the subsequent changes in convective cloud and precipitation development over the tropical Eastern Atlantic Ocean. To fully investigate these changes, multi-platform and multi-sensor observations were combined with cloud-resolving numerical simulations in order to compare and validate observational studies.

The numerical simulations featured an explicit cloud microphysics scheme, which has been updated to connect the presence of dust with a wide variety of ice formation mechanisms over a range of temperatures between 0C and -38C. The microphysical scheme allows for naturally evolving size distributions of liquid drops and ice particles, rather than assuming that each particle type possesses a predetermined and unchanging size distribution. Such predetermined size distributions are typically used in simpler cloud microphysics schemes.  The evolving size distributions used in the simulations track the hydrometeors from initial formation, during growth by vapor diffusion and particle collision, vertical and horizontal transport, formation of precipitation, evaporation/sublimation, and eventual removal from the clouds to the surface. The particle size distributions used in our simulations can be easily converted to equivalent radar reflectivity values, allowing us to directly compare our results with real world observations.

Results from the numerical simulations report that the presence of dust increases the formation of small ice particles at temperatures warmer than -10C. This results in a more competitive growth environment that delays the formation of precipitation to colder temperatures. The greater mass of small ice increases latent heat release around 6km, which invigorates convection and increases the transport of hydrometeor mass into the adjacent stratiform clouds and water vapor into the upper atmosphere. The delayed precipitation formation results in smaller particles near the surface and larger particles near the cloud tops. Due to these changes, radar reflectivity was reduced near surface and increased above the freezing level, which is consistent with our observational studies. The narrower size distribution of particles results in lower average cloud top height despite the stronger convective intensity, due to the faster settling rates of the larger particles and stronger internal circulations within the cloud. The more competitive growth environment resulted in less efficient graupel formation, which reduced surface accumulation of convective precipitation. Greater total ice mass increased snow formation in the adjacent stratiform clouds, which increased surface accumulation of stratiform precipitation. However, total surface precipitation accumulation was reduced, due to the dominating contribution of convective precipitation.

This award was used to support a graduate student’s Ph.D. dissertation research which is expected to be completed winter 2016. This research included performing multiple simulations of test cases and making significant improvements to the cloud microphysics scheme. These improvements include updated ice formation mechanisms, improved radar reflectivity simulation from the particle size distributions, and the incorporation of an evolving ice crystal shape to study the effects of shape changes on cloud microphysical processes and radar reflectivity. The student presented results at several conferences to introduce this research to the wider scientific community.

In addition to these numerical studies, several observational studies were undertaken by postdocs and students in order to more fully understand the microphysical effects of dust on convective cloud systems and to validate the use of multi-platform and multi-sensor retrievals in the study of these effects.
